child.pub-comments: Ethnologue has Parakanã (Parakanân, Parocana, Awaeté) as “a member of the Akwáwa cluster.” Ethnologue presents Suruí do Pará (Akewere, Akewara, Aikewara, "Mudjétira", "Mudjetíre", "Mudjetíre-Suruí", Suruí) as a separate language, a “member of the Akwáwa cluster.”
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.alt-names: Assurini, Asuriní do Tocantins, Asuriní do Trocará, Akwáwa

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue lists as distinct languages Urumi and Karo (Itogapúk, Itogapuc, Ntogapig, Ntogapid, Ramarama, Itanga, Arara-Karo, Uruku, Arára do Jiparaná, Arára), saying it has a dialect “Karo.”

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue considers Itogapuk an alternative name for Karo

child.pub-comments: Akuntsú may be a dialect of Mekens or a distinct language closely related to Mekens. Campbell signifies that Amniape is extinct, but none of the other alternate names and it is unclear from the source why he does so.

child.pub-comments: Rodrigues (1999:109) lists Cinta-Larga and Zoro as independent languages in the Mondé branch; Ethnologue also has Cinta Larga as distinct Mondé language; it lists Gavião do Jiparaná (Gavião do Rondônia, Digüt, Ikõro) as a distinct language (with dialects: Gavião, Zoró (Panginey, Cabeça Seca), said to be “partially intelligible with Suruí.”
